user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of recv_param_adapter:
```c
static ssize_t
recv_param_adapter (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    void *other,
                    size_t i)
{
  ssize_t ret;

  if ( (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == connection->socket_fd) ||
       (MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED == connection->state) )
  {
    return MHD_ERR_NOTCONN_;
  }
  if (i > MHD_SCKT_SEND_MAX_SIZE_)
    i = MHD_SCKT_SEND_MAX_SIZE_; /* return value limit */

  ret = MHD_recv_ (connection->socket_fd,
                   other,
                   i);
  if (0 > ret)
  {
    const int err = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EAGAIN_ (err))
    {
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
      /* Got EAGAIN --- no longer read-ready */
      connection->epoll_state &=
        ~((enum MHD_EpollState) MHD_EPOLL_STATE_READ_READY);
#endif /* EPOLL_SUPPORT */
      return MHD_ERR_AGAIN_;
    }
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_ (err))
      return MHD_ERR_AGAIN_;
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_REMOTE_DISCNN_ (err))
      return MHD_ERR_CONNRESET_;
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err, MHD_SCKT_EOPNOTSUPP_))
      return MHD_ERR_OPNOTSUPP_;
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err, MHD_SCKT_ENOTCONN_))
      return MHD_ERR_NOTCONN_;
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err, MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_))
      return MHD_ERR_INVAL_;
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_LOW_RESOURCES_ (err))
      return MHD_ERR_NOMEM_;
    if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err, MHD_SCKT_EBADF_))
      return MHD_ERR_BADF_;
    /* Treat any other error as a hard error. */
    return MHD_ERR_NOTCONN_;
  }
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
  else if (i > (size_t) ret)
    connection->epoll_state &=
      ~((enum MHD_EpollState) MHD_EPOLL_STATE_READ_READY);
#endif /* EPOLL_SUPPORT */
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (i > MHD_SCKT_SEND_MAX_SIZE_)
    i = MHD_SCKT_SEND_MAX_SIZE_; /* return value limit */
explanation: I selected all conditional branches and return paths that could be (or appear to be) unreachable or warrant investigation for reachability: the initial early-return on invalid socket/closed connection, the whole error-handling branch for ret < 0 (including each error-specific if/return and the final fall-through return), the EPOLL_SUPPORT "else if" branch that depends on ret being non-negative, the size-clamping of i, and the direct call that yields ret. These are the places where control-flow could be rendered unreachable by platform-specific macro definitions, overlapping/mapped error codes, preprocessor configuration, or API guarantees (e.g. MHD_recv_ behavior). Other fragments were not included because they are simple declarations, straightforward assignments, or final return paths that follow directly from the shown branches (for example the function-prologue, the ssize_t ret declaration, the function footer "return ret;" and comments). Those remaining lines are normal, syntactically reachable code given the surrounding control flow and do not on their face present additional potential unreachable-code issues beyond the conditional/return points already reported.
